title: How to build a high-performing growth team | Adam Fishman (Patreon, Lyft, Imperfect Foods)
key_insights: Onboarding is the only product experience 100% of users touch and represents the first chance to deliver on brand promises
When hiring growth people, focus on customer knowledge and execution skills for junior hires rather than looking for unicorns
Internal hires often outperform external ones for growth roles due to existing customer knowledge and cultural fit
Onboarding improvements can shift retention curves by 10-20 percentage points by focusing on habit formation
Use proxy metrics instead of waiting 90 days to measure onboarding success - look for early velocity indicators
The PMF framework (People, Mission, Financials) helps evaluate companies as thoroughly as you'd evaluate investment opportunities
Back-channel references and observing team dynamics are crucial for assessing cultural fit before joining
Growth execution and customer knowledge are foundational competencies that are harder to teach than strategy

guest_background.current_role: EIR at Reforge, Growth Advisor, Newsletter Writer

topics_discussed: Growth Competency Model framework with four main components
Hiring junior vs senior growth talent strategies
Internal vs external hiring for growth roles
Onboarding as retention lever vs conversion optimization
Patreon creator onboarding and human intervention strategies
Opinionated defaults and smart defaults in product design
Proxy metrics for measuring long-term retention impact
PMF framework for candidate company evaluation
Common mistakes founders make when hiring growth people
Growth loop modeling and capital allocation
Communication and influence in growth roles
Career transition stories from marketing to growth
memorable_quotes: Onboarding is the only part of your product experience that a hundred percent of people are ever going to touch. Good luck getting a hundred percent feature adoption of anything else in your product.
When you're interviewing at a company, you are actually investing an even more scarce resource. You're investing your time. There is no way to get more time.
I like to think of your brand is the promise that you're making and your product experience is your delivery of that promise. And those two things have to be in lockstep with each other.
frameworks_mentioned: Growth Competency Model (4 components: Growth Execution, Customer Knowledge, Growth Strategy, Communication & Influence)
Painter vs Architect vs Surgeon hiring archetypes
recommended_for: product managers working on onboarding flows
summary: Adam Fishman shares his Growth Competency Model for hiring and evaluating growth talent, deep dives into onboarding optimization strategies that can improve retention by 10-20%, and introduces his PMF framework for candidates to evaluate companies as rigorously as investment opportunities.
